citations.narrative:
Two primary enclosures were in poor repair.
- The outdoor wire fencing around the enclosure housing 15 goats and 5 sheep contained many sharp points pointing
inwards towards the animals in the enclosure.
- The enclosure housing 24 prairie dogs failed to contain the animals. A prairie dog was observed 20 feet away from the
primary enclosure, sticking it’s head out of a hole in the ground. The facility manager stated that the prairie dogs had
tunneled out of the primary enclosure into adjacent enclosures.
Sharp edges and points in enclosures can lead to injury of the animals. Animals that escape their primary enclosures may
experience stress, injury, predation or death. Correct by ensuring that the outdoor housing facilities are structurally sound
and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain them.
CORRECT BY : 11/9/2023

A large amount of rodent droppings were present in the animal food prep area, the shed where feed and medication is
stored, and a live rat was present in the primary enclosure housing two adult male ring-tailed lemurs. Rodents can cause
contamination and spoilage of feed, and rodents can carry diseases that are harmful to animals. Correct by establishing
and maintaining a safe and effective program for the control of pests including rodents. The pest control program must
also be maintained in accordance with 3.84(d).

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At time of the inspection this facility has not documented a written plan for environmental enhancement for birds, although
they do provide enrichment for the resident birds. Birds have complex social and environmental needs, and failure to
provide for these needs may result in stress, obesity, or the development of abnormal/harmful behaviors. Dealers,
exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement.
The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must address the social needs of birds, their environment,
and special considerations for young birds, birds showing signs of distress, and social birds housed alone. CORRECT BY
: 10/26/2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
Additional Inspectors:
DIANA CARE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
Two primary enclosures were in poor repair.  
- The outdoor wire fencing around the enclosure housing 15 goats and 5 sheep contained many sharp points pointing 
inwards towards the animals in the enclosure.  
- The enclosure housing 24 prairie dogs failed to contain the animals. A prairie dog was observed 20 feet away from the 
primary enclosure, sticking it’s head out of a hole in the ground. The facility manager stated that the prairie dogs had 
tunneled out of the primary enclosure into adjacent enclosures.  
Sharp edges and points in enclosures can lead to injury of the animals. Animals that escape their primary enclosures may 
experience stress, injury, predation or death. Correct by ensuring that the outdoor housing facilities are structurally sound 
and maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain them. 
CORRECT BY : 11/9/2023 
3.131(d)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
A large amount of rodent droppings were present in the animal food prep area, the shed where feed and medication is 
stored, and a live rat was present in the primary enclosure housing two adult male ring-tailed lemurs. Rodents can cause 
contamination and spoilage of feed, and rodents can carry diseases that are harmful to animals. Correct by establishing 
and maintaining a safe and effective program for the control of pests including rodents. The pest control program must 
also be maintained in accordance with 3.84(d). 
3.154 
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
At time of the inspection this facility has not documented a written plan for environmental enhancement for birds, although 
they do provide enrichment for the resident birds. Birds have complex social and environmental needs, and failure to 
provide for these needs may result in stress, obesity, or the development of abnormal/harmful behaviors. Dealers, 
exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment enhancement. 
The plan must be approved by the attending veterinarian and must address the social needs of birds, their environment, 
and special considerations for young birds, birds showing signs of distress, and social birds housed alone. CORRECT BY 
: 10/26/2023

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
DIANA CARE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
